headline.main: Diabetes Is Seen As a Rising Risk In Mothers-to-Be

docs.abstract: Gestational diabetes, temporary form of diabetes that occurs in some pregnant women, has risen by nearly 50 percent in New York in about 10 years; there is broader recognition that arrival of condition is significant and its impact can be grave: not only does it identify those women at high risk to develop permanent diabetes, but it may contribute to their babies eventually getting diabetes as well; health care officials worry that insufficient attention is being paid to rising number of cases, apparently being propelled by genetically susceptible women entering pregnancy too fat; graph; photo (M)
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: It has long been something of a quirk in the grim universe of diabetes: a small number of pregnant women would become temporarily diabetic. With proper care, the consequences were often thought to be mild. The babies were usually healthy. And the condition would vanish after the delivery, like a cough or a headache. But, not unlike the wider expansion of diabetes, this disorder is now growing, and indications are that it is growing fast. In New York, so-called gestational diabetes has risen by nearly 50 percent in about 10 years.

headline.main: Low-Fat Milk And Obesity in Kids

docs.abstract: Health and Mental Hygiene Dept Deputy Comr Mary Bassett letter supports decision to remove whole milk from New York City public school cafeterias
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Thinning the Milk Does Not Mean Thinning the Child'' (Week in Review, Feb. 12): Obesity is epidemic in New York City. With 1.2 million obese adults and half of kindergartners at an unhealthy weight, public health action is necessary.
